history.content: I was in a similar situation as you, and learned a lot about how real software engineering is done through an internship. Try to get one for next summer!

children.subject: Try to take more project based classes like 61C, 169, 161, 162, 184, 188, etc. 169 in particular teaches many skills needed for an internship. You can also try writing some code on your own; you don't have to do a giant project from scratch to improve your coding skills. You can also consider joining a club that does some coding.

@anon the point of an internship is for a company to help you learn software engineering principles that you seldom would have the opportunity to pick up outside of an industry work environment. If you get one, it's because your team is confident in your ability to learn the required SWE chops, not because they're already expecting you to have them.

Yeah I feel like if I were to get an internship, I would learn a lot about real software engineering.

My concern is that without side project experience, even if I can solve random algorithm interview questions, I will struggle very hard in an internship. Also, I don't think I can get any interviews in the first place.

history.content:
Hi,

Rising sophomore, got an A in 61b with hug and taking 170 in fall. Strong at math in general and feeling relatively confident about the coding interview

However, before college I had no coding experience and during school/summer, I had no time to do sideprojects (took cs70). I feel very weak about coding itself. Although familiar with OOP from class, I have never done a full project and am afraid of my real life coding skills.

Should this be of concern?
history.subject: Good at interview questions but bad at actual coding
